A quiet backwater, and largely unspoilt coastal region. The landscape is mostly flat and agricultural populated by quaint, if unremarkable towns and villages.  The real highlight is the coastline itself, which ranges from the sandy beaches of
The A149 is an 85 mile long road from
the road follows the coastline. To access Cromer from King's Lynn, you can use the A148, passing through West Norfolk,

, but the A149 is a scenic route, following the coastline and passing through the small villages of North Norfolk. Not a recommended route for HGVs, tourists can use this road to go to a number of places, including many of the attractions mentioned in this article.
The road passes through the ever-changing, agricultural and coastal landscape of North Norfolk, and don't be surprised about the small narrow sections of road, namely in

.
Part of Cycling Route 1 that runs along the North Norfolk Coastline uses the A149, a recommended local cycling route.

The most useful route for exploring the North Norfolk coast is the Coasthopper

Take a ferry to see the Common and Grey seals at

.  Departure times and availability depend on the tides. The ferry stays within the harbor and doesn't venture to the open sea. Morston is the more interesting place to depart from. You can always pop over to the Anchor Pub to warm up afterwards. Trips are operated by the following companies:

In case of emergency at sea, dial 999 and ask for "Coastguard".

There is a lifeguard service at

. This operates daily from June until the first week in September, from 10:00 to 18:00. The lifeguarded zone is defined by red and yellow flags on the beach, with the beach lifeguard station also flying a red and yellow flag. Do not swim if a red flag is flying.

On occasion live ammunition and unexploded bombs from World War II have been found on the coast.  If you do come across a suspicious item leave it alone and report it to the coast guard.

This is a tidal region so be careful, especially with young children.
